title: Cushing Disease due to ACTH-Secreting Pituitary Adenoma
setup_script: “A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive weight gain, facial rounding, purple abdominal striae, and hypertension. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol and lack of suppression with low-dose dexamethasone. ACTH is elevated. Pituitary MRI reveals a 6 mm microadenoma. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “What etiologies of hypercortisolism would you consider?”
“Midnight salivary cortisol is elevated, high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression, and CRH stimulation increases ACTH levels. How do you interpret these results?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends medical optimization before surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: “Endocrinology recommends ketoconazole for temporary cortisol control. What other preoperative evaluations are needed?”
“Visual fields are intact. How do you counsel the patient regarding surgery?”
“The patient consents after counseling about potential complications including CSF leak, hypopituitarism, and diabetes insipidus. What are your next steps?”
“Intraoperatively, you resect a small pituitary lesion. Pathology confirms ACTH-secreting corticotroph adenoma. What is your postoperative management?”
“Postoperative morning cortisol is 2 μg/dL. The patient is fatigued and hypotensive. How do you manage this?”
“The patient improves on hydrocortisone. What complications will you monitor for in the immediate postoperative period?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions visual changes, diabetes insipidus, or infection
dynamic_flow.reply: “No acute complications develop. What is your follow-up plan with endocrinology?”
“Cortisol monitoring and periodic MRI are arranged. How would you manage residual or recurrent disease?”
“Endocrinology reviews options including repeat surgery, radiation, or medical therapy. What education will you provide to the patient before discharge?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident mentions adrenal insufficiency education
dynamic_flow.reply: “The patient is given a medical alert bracelet and stress dosing instructions. Case concludes.”

critical_decision_points: Differentiating causes of hypercortisolism and confirming pituitary source.
Planning and coordinating transsphenoidal surgery with the multidisciplinary team.
Establishing long-term surveillance for recurrence and hypopituitarism.

Your clinical judgment in planning transsphenoidal surgery was timely and well-structured. Communication with the multidisciplinary team was clear and professional.Areas for Improvement: Earlier discussion of alternative etiologies of ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome would strengthen your differential.
